name: hc_gdcflex_rf_available
description: [HC] GDC-FLEX RF ‚Üí PASS (5 materials available incl. RF)
query: Pharmaceutical rooftop installation. We want GDC-FLEX in Stainless Steel (RF). Airflow: 1750 m¬≥/h. Please confirm availability.

turns.content: Pharmaceutical rooftop installation. We want GDC-FLEX in Stainless Steel (RF). Airflow: 1750 m¬≥/h. Please confirm availability.

For your pharmaceutical rooftop installation, the GDC_FLEX filter is not suitable due to particulate and condensation risks. Particulate Exposure from the cleanroom environment requires mechanical filtration, while GDC_FLEX uses carbon adsorption which is ineffective against solid particulates. Additionally, Outdoor Condensation on the non-insulated housing can lead to corrosion. Finally, the bolted construction of the GDC_FLEX does not meet the Hygiene Requirements for pharmaceutical environments.Therefore, the GDC_FLEX is blocked for this application. Instead, I recommend a two-stage filtration system using the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p, which is approved for pharmaceutical environments. This system will protect against both particulate and chemical vapor exposure.This multi-stage assembly consists of a GDP Planfiltersk√•p (Stage 1) for mechanical filtration to capture particulates, protecting the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p (Stage 2) which uses carbon adsorption to remove chemical vapors. Both stages will use 600x600mm housings to match your required airflow of 1750 m¬≥/h.To finalize the configuration, I need two details:First, what is the filter depth you need for the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p (Stage 2)?Second, to mitigate the risk of Outdoor Condensation, I need to know the minimum expected ambient temperature and typical relative humidity at the installation site.

stages.reason: Particulate environments require mechanical pre-filtration before carbon to prevent physical pore blockage.
Replaces GDC_FLEX family (blocked by installation constraint). Approved for ENV_PHARMACEUTICAL environment

content_segments.text: For your pharmaceutical rooftop installation, the GDC_FLEX filter is not suitable due to particulate and condensation risks. Particulate Exposure from the cleanroom environment requires mechanical filtration, while GDC_FLEX uses carbon adsorption which is ineffective against solid particulates. Additionally, Outdoor Condensation on the non-insulated housing can lead to corrosion. Finally, the bolted construction of the GDC_FLEX does not meet the Hygiene Requirements for pharmaceutical environments.

Therefore, the GDC_FLEX is blocked for this application. Instead, I recommend a two-stage filtration system using the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p, which is approved for pharmaceutical environments. This system will protect against both particulate and chemical vapor exposure.

This multi-stage assembly consists of a GDP Planfiltersk√•p (Stage 1) for mechanical filtration to capture particulates, protecting the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p (Stage 2) which uses carbon adsorption to remove chemical vapors. Both stages will use 600x600mm housings to match your required airflow of 1750 m¬≥/h.
To finalize the configuration, I need two details:
First, what is the filter depth you need for the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p (Stage 2)?
content_segments.inference_logic: Filter depth determines the housing length required to accommodate the filter.

content_segments.text: Second, to mitigate the risk of Outdoor Condensation, I need to know the minimum expected ambient temperature and typical relative humidity at the installation site.
content_segments.inference_logic: This data is needed to assess the risk of condensation and determine if additional insulation is required.
